H0.text: The rotation of Earth is the factor that most contributes to the variation in the Sun’s path across the sky during the year, with the Sun appearing higher on the horizon in summer and lower in winter in the Northern Hemisphere.

H1.text: The tilted axis of Earth is the factor that most contributes to the variation in the Sun’s path across the sky, making the Sun appear higher on the horizon during Northern Hemisphere summer and lower during winter.

H2.text: The flattening of Earth at the poles is the factor that most contributes to the variation in the Sun’s apparent path across the sky throughout the year, causing the Sun to appear higher on the horizon in summer and lower in winter in the Northern Hemisphere.

H3.text: The elliptical shape of the orbit of Earth is the factor that most contributes to the variation in the path of the Sun across the sky, causing the Sun to appear higher on the horizon during summer and lower during winter in the Northern Hemisphere.

A4.text: Earth's axis remains tilted in the same direction with reference to the background stars throughout a year – this is the cause of Earth's seasons.

A5.text: Variations in Earth's axial tilt can influence the seasons and is likely a factor in long-term climatic change.
